classes.name: Cleric
classes.description:
The most common type of priest is the cleric. The cleric may be an adherent of any religion (though if the DM designs a specific mythos, the cleric's abilities and spells may be changed—see following). Clerics are generally good, but are not restricted to good; they can have any alignment acceptable to their order. A cleric must have a Wisdom score of 9 or more. High constitution and Charisma are also particularly useful.

A cleric who has a Wisdom of 16 or more gains a 10% bonus to the experience points he earns.

The cleric class is similar to certain religious orders of knighthood of the Middle Ages: the Teutonic Knights, the Knights Templars, and Hospitalers. These orders combined military and religious training with a code of protection and service. Members were trained as knights and devoted themselves to the service of the church. These orders were frequently found on the outer edges of the Christian world, either on the fringe of the wilderness or in war-torn lands. Archbishop Turpin (of The Song of Roland) is an example of such a cleric. Similar orders can also be found in other lands, such as the sohei of Japan.

Clerics are sturdy soldiers, although their selection of weapons is limited. They can wear any type of armor and use any shield. Standard clerics, being reluctant to shed blood or spread violence, are allowed to use only blunt, bludgeoning weapons. They can use a fair number of magical items including priest scrolls, most potions and rings, some wands and rods, staves, armor, shields, and magical versions of any weapons allowed by their order.

Spells are the main tools of the cleric, helping him to serve, fortify, protect, and revitalize those under his care. He has a wide variety of spells to choose from, suitable to many different purposes and needs. (A priest of a specific mythos probably has a more restricted range of spells.) A cleric has major access to every sphere of influence except the plant, animal, weather, and elemental spheres (he has minor access to the elemental sphere and cannot cast spells of the other three spheres).

The cleric receives his spells as insight directly from his deity (the deity does not need to make a personal appearance to grant the spells the cleric prays for), as a sign of and reward for his faith, so he must take care not to abuse his power lest it be taken away as punishment.

The cleric is also granted power over undead — evil creatures that exist in a form of non-life, neither dead nor alive. The cleric is charged with defeating these mockeries of life. His ability to turn undead enables him to drive away these creatures or destroy them utterly (though a cleric of evil alignment can bind the creatures to his will). Some of the more common undead creatures are ghosts, zombies, skeletons, ghouls, and mummies. Vampires and liches (undead sorcerers) are two of the most powerful undead.

As a cleric advances in level, he gains additional spells, better combat skills, and a stronger turning ability. Upon reaching 8th level, the cleric automatically attracts a fanatically loyal group of believers, provided the character has established a place of worship of significant size. The cleric can build this place of worship at any time during his career, but he does not attract believers until he reaches 8th level.

At 9th level, the cleric may receive official approval to establish a religious stronghold, be it a fortified abbey or a secluded convent. Obviously, the stronghold must contain all the trappings of a place of worship and must be dedicated to the service of the cleric's cause. However, the construction cost of the stronghold is half the normal price, since the work has official sanction and much of the labor is donated. The cleric can hold property and build a stronghold any time before reaching 9th level, but this is done without church sanction and does not receive the benefits described above.
special_abilities: Turn Undead: Beginning at 1st level, Clerics can repel, destroy, or command undead creatures. The ability improves with level and depends on the type of undead encountered.
Can cast spells starting at 1st level, granted by divine forces.
Use any armor and shields.
Limited to blunt weapons (mace, staff, hammer, etc.).
Can use magical items such as armor, weapons, rods, potions, scrolls.

classes.name: Druid
classes.description:
Druids are priests of nature and neutrality. They are the guardians of the wilderness and protectors of the balance of the land. Druids are responsible for preserving the natural order, maintaining the balance between the elements, and ensuring that neither good nor evil, law nor chaos, gains the upper hand. Druids are aloof from the more mundane aspects of mankind and prefer the company of animals and plants over civilization.

Druids must have a minimum Wisdom of 12 and a Charisma of 15. Only humans and half-elves can become druids. Their prime requisites are Wisdom and Charisma.

Druids use the same attack rolls and saving throws as clerics. They can wear only natural armors, such as leather or padded, and cannot use metal armor. They are allowed to use wooden shields. Druids can only use weapons of natural make: club, dagger, dart, spear, scimitar, sickle, sling, and staff.

Druids are immune to charm spells cast by woodland creatures (such as dryads, nixies, and sylphs). At 3rd level, a druid gains the ability to identify plants and animals, and to pass through overgrown areas without leaving a trail. Also at 3rd level, druids learn a secret language used to communicate with other druids.

At 7th level, a druid gains the ability to shapechange into a reptile, bird, and mammal, once each per day. Each form can be assumed once per day. When shapechanging, the druid heals 10-60% of all damage he has taken (round fractions down). At 7th level, druids become immune to charm spells cast by woodland creatures.

A druid must maintain a neutral alignment. Advancement to higher levels requires defeating other druids in ritual combat for positions of leadership. At the highest levels, druids become Hierophants of the Forest and cease advancing in hit dice or attack rolls, but continue gaining spells and influence.

classes.name: Fighter
classes.description:
Fighters are warriors, experts in weapons, tactics, and strategy. They can be found in all walks of life, from peasant militia to noble knights. Fighters are trained in the use of all armors, shields, and weapons, and their primary role is physical combat. In battle, fighters are the backbone of any fighting force.

A fighter must have a Strength score of 9 or more. Those with Strength scores of 16 or more gain a 10% bonus to the experience points they earn.

Fighters are the only class that can attain Weapon Specialization. Specialization allows a fighter to become especially proficient with a particular weapon, gaining bonuses to hit and damage.

At 9th level, fighters can establish a stronghold and attract men-at-arms and elite household guards to serve them. They are known for their ability to hold and defend territory.

Fighters can use any magical weapon, armor, shield, or item available to warriors, and they are proficient with all types of armor and weapons.
special_abilities: Weapon Specialization: Fighters are the only class allowed to specialize in weapons, gaining bonuses to hit and damage.
Multiple Attacks: Fighters gain extra melee attacks at higher levels.
At 9th level, can establish a stronghold and attract men-at-arms and elite household guards.
Able to use any weapon and wear any armor.
Can use many magical items (potions, protection scrolls, most rings, enchanted weapons, shields, armor).

classes.name: Paladin
classes.description:
The paladin is a warrior dedicated to the forces of good. She is the noble champion of law and good, a knight whose very presence inspires others. To become a paladin, a character must meet strict ability requirements: Strength 12, Constitution 9, Wisdom 13, and Charisma 17. Paladins must be of lawful good alignment and must maintain a strict moral code.

Paladins detect evil at a distance of 60 feet by concentrating. They receive a +2 bonus to all saving throws and are immune to all forms of disease. Once per day, they can lay on hands to heal 2 hit points per level. Paladins can cure disease once per week per five levels. They project a protective aura against evil summoned creatures. At 3rd level, paladins can turn undead as a cleric two levels lower. At 4th level, a paladin may call for a bonded warhorse. At 9th level, paladins gain the ability to cast priest spells from specific spheres. Paladins must adhere to strict rules regarding the accumulation of wealth, the number of magical items possessed, and the types of followers hired. A paladin who strays from the path of lawful good loses all special abilities until penance is made.

Immune to all diseases (magical curses like mummy rot are not diseases).

classes.name: Ranger
classes.description:
The ranger is a hunter and woodsman who lives by not only his sword, but also his wits. Robin Hood, Orion, Jack the giant killer, and the huntresses of Diana are examples of rangers from history and legend. The abilities of the ranger make him particularly good at tracking, woodcraft, and spying.

A ranger must have scores not less than 13 in Strength, 13 in Dexterity, 14 in Constitution, and 14 in Wisdom. The prime requisites of the ranger are Strength, Dexterity, and Wisdom. Rangers are always good, but can be lawful, neutral, or chaotic.

Rangers can use any weapon and wear any armor, although several special abilities are usable only when wearing studded leather or lighter armor. They can fight two-handed without penalty if lightly armored. They automatically gain tracking proficiency and can move silently and hide in shadows when in light armor.

Before advancing to 2nd level, a ranger must select a species enemy. Whenever the ranger encounters that enemy, he gains a +4 bonus to attack rolls and suffers a -4 penalty on encounter reactions.

Rangers have limited animal empathy, being able to befriend and calm wild animals. At 8th level, rangers gain limited priest spells from the plant and animal spheres. At 10th level, they attract 2d6 followers (which may be humans, animals, or magical creatures). Rangers must always maintain a good alignment, and violating this causes permanent loss of ranger status.

Followers: Attract 2d6 followers at 10th level (humans, animals, magical creatures).

classes.name: Mage
classes.description:
Mages are powerful spellcasters whose study of magic gives them access to a vast array of magical spells. They are often scholars, researchers, and explorers of ancient lore and arcane secrets. Mages must have an Intelligence of 9 or more to become a wizard. Their primary attribute is Intelligence, which affects their ability to learn and cast spells.

Mages are extremely limited in their choice of weapons and cannot wear armor. They rely on spells, wits, and magical items for defense and offense. At higher levels, mages gain the ability to craft magical items such as scrolls, potions, and later more powerful artifacts. They have the broadest access to magical items among all classes.

Through their mastery of magic, mages can influence the battlefield, deceive enemies, summon creatures, and harness the elements. However, they are physically weak and vulnerable without their spells.
special_abilities: Cast spells starting at 1st level.
Learn, prepare, and cast a wide variety of spells.
Craft scrolls and potions starting at 9th level.
Later able to create more powerful magical items (at higher levels).
Access to the greatest variety of magical items.

classes.name: Specialist Mage
classes.description:
Specialist mages are wizards who focus their magical studies on one specific school of magic. Through intense study and dedication, they gain extra abilities with spells of their chosen school. In exchange, they sacrifice access to other schools of magic.

Specialist mages memorize one additional spell per spell level from their school of specialization. Enemies suffer a -1 penalty on saving throws against spells from the specialist's school. The specialist also gains a +1 bonus on saving throws against spells from their own school.

Specialists cannot cast spells from certain prohibited schools and must have specific ability scores depending on their chosen specialty.

Each specialist mage belongs to one of the eight primary schools of magic: Abjuration, Conjuration/Summoning, Greater Divination, Enchantment/Charm, Illusion, Invocation/Evocation, Necromancy, or Alteration.
special_abilities: Gain one additional memorized spell per spell level from their school of specialization.

classes.name: Thief
classes.description:
Thieves are skilled rogues who excel in stealth, subterfuge, and agility. They rely on quick wits and dexterity to overcome obstacles and defeat foes. Thieves prefer to avoid direct confrontation, instead using cunning and stealth.

### Thief Abilities
**Pick Pockets**: Filch small items from others without their notice. A failed attempt may be noticed.

**Open Locks**: Unlock doors or containers with thieves' tools. Cannot open locks magically sealed unless specified.

**Find/Remove Traps**: Detect and disable mechanical traps. Magical traps cannot be detected unless specified.

**Move Silently**: Move without making noise. A failed roll alerts nearby creatures.

**Hide in Shadows**: Blend into shadows to become almost invisible. Movement usually spoils hiding.

**Detect Noise**: Listen for faint sounds such as whispered conversations or footsteps behind doors.

**Climb Walls**: Climb vertical or near-vertical surfaces that others cannot.

**Read Languages**: Read unfamiliar languages with increasing skill as levels advance. Magical writings are excluded.

### Backstab
When a thief strikes an unaware opponent from behind, he gains bonuses to attack rolls and increased damage. Damage multipliers increase with level.

### Followers
At 10th level, thieves attract a band of followers consisting of rogues, mercenaries, and specialists.

At 1st level, thieves receive 60 discretionary points to distribute among their thief abilities. Each subsequent level, they receive an additional 30 points to assign.

classes.name: Bard
classes.description:
Bards are magical performers who combine the talents of warriors, thieves, and wizards. They have learned the arts of music, storytelling, and spellcasting to inspire and charm others. Bards use their abilities to perform, influence, and help their allies while weaving magic through their melodies. A bard can cast spells from the Wizard spell list but cannot specialize in any one school of magic.

### Bardic Skills
Bards gain the following abilities, similar to thieves: Pick Pockets, Open Locks, Find/Remove Traps, Move Silently, Hide in Shadows, Detect Noise, Climb Walls, and Read Languages. The base values for these skills are the same as for thieves, but the bard starts with 20 discretionary points to assign and gains an additional 15 points per level thereafter.

### Bardic Music
Bards can use their musical talents to influence others, increasing morale, inspiring courage, and even counteracting other magical effects. At higher levels, bards gain the ability to inspire allies, making them more effective in combat or able to negate magical effects through Counter Song.

### Lore
Bards also gain knowledge about magical items, having a 5% chance per level to identify any magic item they encounter.

### Spellcasting
Bards can cast spells starting at 2nd level. They use the same spell progression as wizards and can learn spells from the Wizard spell list.

### Other Abilities
Bards gain the ability to use scrolls at 10th level (though there is a 15% chance of mishap). At 9th level, they also attract followers.
